title: P06-1053

sentences.text: The psycholinguistic literature provides evidence for syntactic priming , i.e. , the tendency to repeat structures .
This paper describes a method for incorporating priming into an incremental probabilistic parser .
Three models are compared , which involve priming of rules between sentences , within sentences , and within coordinate structures .
These models simulate the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data , and also yield a small increase in overall parsing accuracy .

Entity-these_model.label: These models
Entity-these_model.description: Three incremental probabilistic parser models that incorporate syntactic priming to simulate the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data and improve overall parsing accuracy.

Entity-a_method_for_incorporating_primin.label: a method for incorporating priming into an incremental probabilistic parser
aliases: a method for incorporating priming into an incremental probabilistic parser
Entity-a_method_for_incorporating_primin.description: A technique that integrates syntactic priming into an incremental probabilistic parsing model, allowing for the simulation of reading time advantages and increased parsing accuracy.

mentions.local_name: a method for incorporating priming into an incremental probabilistic parser

Entity-three_model_are_compared__which_i.label: Three models are compared, which involve priming of rules between sentences, within sentences, and within coordinate structures
aliases: Three models are compared, which involve priming of rules between sentences, within sentences, and within coordinate structures
Entity-three_model_are_compared__which_i.description: The three linguistic models being compared incorporate syntactic priming by applying rule-based priming mechanisms across sentence boundaries, within individual sentences, and within coordinated structures.

mentions.local_name: Three models are compared, which involve priming of rules between sentences, within sentences, and within coordinate structures

Entity-these_model_simulate_the_reading_.label: These models simulate the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data, and also yield a small increase in overall parsing accuracy
aliases: These models simulate the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data, and also yield a small increase in overall parsing accuracy
Entity-these_model_simulate_the_reading_.description: Three incremental probabilistic parser models compared in this paper, which simulate the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data and yield a small increase in overall parsing accuracy.

mentions.local_name: These models simulate the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data, and also yield a small increase in overall parsing accuracy

Entity-priming.label: priming
Entity-priming.description: The phenomenon of syntactically repeating structures, often observed in human language processing and incorporated into natural language processing models to simulate reading time advantages.

Entity-priming_of_rule_between_sentence_.label: priming of rules between sentences, within sentences, and within coordinate structures
aliases: priming of rules between sentences, within sentences, and within coordinate structures
Entity-priming_of_rule_between_sentence_.description: The process of applying syntactic priming to influence the application of parsing rules across sentence boundaries, as well as within individual sentences and coordinate structures.

mentions.local_name: priming of rules between sentences, within sentences, and within coordinate structures

Entity-this_paper.label: This paper
Entity-this_paper.description: A research paper that describes a method for incorporating syntactic priming into an incremental probabilistic parser.

Entity-priming_of_rule.label: priming of rules
Entity-priming_of_rule.description: The process or phenomenon where linguistic rules are influenced by previously encountered sentence structures to repeat similar patterns.

Entity-syntactic_priming.label: syntactic priming
Entity-syntactic_priming.description: The phenomenon of being influenced in one's linguistic behavior by a previously encountered sentence structure.

Entity-the_reading_time_advantage_for_pa.label: the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data
aliases: the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data
Entity-the_reading_time_advantage_for_pa.description: The phenomenon where readers process and comprehend sentences with parallel structures (e.g., 'John likes dogs, Mary likes cats') more quickly than those without such structures.

mentions.local_name: the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data

Entity-a_small_increase_in_overall_parsi.label: a small increase in overall parsing accuracy
aliases: a small increase in overall parsing accuracy
Entity-a_small_increase_in_overall_parsi.description: The improvement in the ability of an incremental probabilistic parser to accurately parse sentences.

mentions.local_name: a small increase in overall parsing accuracy

Entity-incremental_probabilistic_parser.label: incremental probabilistic parser
Entity-incremental_probabilistic_parser.description: A computational tool that uses probability to parse text incrementally, processing and analyzing language as it is received.

Entity-parallel_structure.label: parallel structures
Entity-parallel_structure.description: A grammatical structure where two or more clauses or phrases have similar syntactic patterns.

Entity-reading_time_advantage.label: reading time advantage
Entity-reading_time_advantage.description: The phenomenon of faster reading times for parallel structures found in human data, as simulated by models compared in this paper.

Entity-the_tendency_to_repeat_structure.label: the tendency to repeat structures
Entity-the_tendency_to_repeat_structure.description: A phenomenon where a person or system has a propensity to reuse similar grammatical patterns in their language production.

Entity-rule_between_sentence.label: rules between sentences
Entity-rule_between_sentence.description: A set of linguistic rules that govern the relationships between consecutive sentences in a text.

Entity-within_sentence.label: within sentences
Entity-within_sentence.description: A set of guidelines or principles governing the structure or organization of linguistic units at a specific level.

Entity-coordinate_structure.label: coordinate structures
Entity-coordinate_structure.description: A type of linguistic structure that involves a relationship between two or more clauses or phrases.

Entity-the_psycholinguistic_literature.label: The psycholinguistic literature
Entity-the_psycholinguistic_literature.description: A collection of research studies and findings in the field of psychology and linguistics that investigate how language processing affects human behavior.

Entity-psycholinguistic_literature.label: psycholinguistic literature
Entity-psycholinguistic_literature.description: A body of research and scholarly work that explores the relationship between language and psychology.

Entity-three_model.label: Three models
Entity-three_model.description: A set of three distinct conceptual or computational frameworks

Entity-model.label: models
Entity-model.description: A conceptual representation or framework used to explain, predict, or analyze phenomena

Entity-method.label: method
Entity-method.description: A systematic procedure or approach used to achieve a specific goal, outcome, or result.

Entity-human_data.label: human data
Entity-human_data.description: Information or records collected from individuals

summary: The psycholinguistic literature provides evidence for syntactic priming , i.e. , the tendency to repeat structures . This paper describes a method for incorporating priming into an incremental probabilistic parser . Three models are compared , which involve priming of rules between sentences , within sentences , and within coordinate structures . These models simulate the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data , and also yield a small increase in overall parsing accuracy .

Predicate-provides_evidence_for.label: provides evidence for
Predicate-provides_evidence_for.description: The predicate 'provides evidence for' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., research findings, data, or theories) offers support or confirmation for the object (e.g., a hypothesis, theory, or concept). This connection suggests that the information provided by the subject serves as justification or backing for the idea or phenomenon represented by the object.

Predicate-shows.label: shows
Predicate-shows.description: Indicates or reveals a characteristic, property, or phenomenon that exists between the subject and object. The predicate 'shows' highlights an inherent connection or relationship between the two entities.

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' connects the subject to a description or characterization of an object. It indicates that the subject provides information about the nature, characteristics, or essence of the object.

Predicate-incorporates.label: incorporates
Predicate-incorporates.description: The predicate 'incorporates' indicates a relationship where one entity (the subject) integrates or combines another entity (the object), often resulting in a unified, cohesive whole. This integration can occur through various means such as merging, combining, or assimilating the properties or characteristics of the object into the subject.

Predicate-involve.label: involve
Predicate-involve.description: To involve means to engage or participate actively with something, often implying a level of complexity, depth, or nuance. The subject of the predicate 'involve' takes on an active role in relation to the object, which can be a process, concept, activity, or structure. This connection suggests that the subject is deeply invested or committed to the object, and may even shape its nature or characteristics.

Predicate-simulate.label: simulate
Predicate-simulate.description: To simulate means to create a representation or imitation of something that mimics its behavior, characteristics, or effects. In this sense, the predicate 'simulate' connects the subject (the models) with the object (the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data), indicating that the models are creating an artificial environment or scenario that mirrors the real-world phenomenon being studied.

Predicate-yield.label: yield
Predicate-yield.description: The predicate 'yield' indicates that the subject produces or generates the object. It implies a causal relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject's actions or properties lead to the creation of the object.

Predicate-describe.label: describe
Predicate-describe.description: To characterize or outline the essential features of something, typically providing a concise and informative summary. This predicate establishes a connection between its subject (the entity being described) and object (the description itself), indicating that the subject embodies or exemplifies the characteristics outlined by the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is related to or encompasses the object as a more general category. It suggests an hierarchical relationship between the two entities, where the subject represents a higher-level concept and the object represents a lower-level concept within its scope.
